sentence: This study evaluates a foresight analysis based on deliverable 1 – “Algorithmic personalisation, the case of Netflix”¬– in which a literature review was conducted on the ethical and legal issues of Netflix algorithmic recommendation systems.

The interviews will be used as the main resource to analyse the future possible scenarios of Netflix recommendation systems, and this study will offer a guidance into the future of Netflix recommendation systems that can be used for other companies based on algorithmic personalisation, and it also offers insights into the future of Netflix and data-use to regulatory bodies.

Rather than looking at the, often dystopian, movies like ‘Ex Machina’ ‘Chappie’ ‘her’ or ‘Ghost in the shell’, where the portrait of robots and artificial intelligence (AI) is more common, including facial recognition technologies in science fiction , this study offers interviews with experts from which it can be drawn many insights.

The lack of access to people involved in this technology was also a reason to conduct interviews with people in the field, although not working at Netflix, they help to understand the existing technologies and their expert opinions about the future.

The lack of access to people involved in this technology was also a reason to conduct interviews with people in the field, although not working at Netflix, they help to understand the existing technologies and their expert opinions about the future.

Considering the amount of time and resources that this project offers to finalize the deliverable, and the difficulty to reach professionals to conduct interviews (see section below 2.3.1), the final decision was to interview three experts: one expert working in the field of media and economy (Annex 1), one researcher working in the technical field (Annex 2) and a researcher working in the legal field of data protection (Annex 3).

The questions are inspired by the structure of the foresight analysis and methodology of the other case studies from this report  which have used the foresight analysis ‘Assessing Expectations: Towards a Toolbox for an Ethics of Emerging Technologies’ (2011).

These expectations are seen in the difference between how experts communicate in scientific journals rather than to a larger (non-scientific) audience, in the first one scientist try to argue facts but also limitations and controversies in technologies, which are missing while communicating the product to a user or a wider audience.
Sometimes experts can argue that a technology is successful just to get funding or as a marketing promotion, rather than with scientific evidence (Lucivero 2011, p.133-134).

An analysis of the problems/limitations with technologies helps to reduce speculations of the technologies’ potential and helps to show problems with the technology outside ‘the lab’.

Finally, this section also offers an evaluation of the unexpected moral changes that the technology might bring about such as the “mutual shaping of technology and morality that are an important ingredient for fictive, and yet grounded, reflections on future techno-moral change” (idem p. 138).

16.2.1	Brief record of my experience

I started by calling the customer number  (both Spanish and English) where I asked about the recommendation algorithms, but it was not possible to ask relevant questions about them, as in their words, they only answer questions related to the use of the platform and they do not have information about the recommendation algorithms, which they told me to look at the Netflix Blog, where this blog post  is, according to them, the only available resource for information.

16.2.3	Personal data generated from the interviews
As a researcher, I have a duty of confidentiality regarding the data collected.
This means that I undertake, for example in the context of a publication or a conference, never to reveal your name or any other data that could identify you.
I have also asked for their express consent to record the interview, and to keep their names and profiles, except for the focus-groups, which names remain confidential.
The collection and processing of data is in accordance with the legal principles imposed by the new European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which has been in force since 25 May 2018.

In this section I offer an overview of the relevant arguments that I found in the literature that concern the technology and future scenarios of Netflix.
This section will also be used as information to ask the experts during the interviews (see section 2.2.2) and offers the starting point to analyse the future scenarios (see section 2.2).

However, data collection and personalized marketing does not inevitably lead to privacy intrusions or damage the user, as sometimes can benefit consumers, and this is a desirable outcome for the future, however it is questioned whether this pervasive form of marketing should be more transparent and whether Netflix should offer more control over user’s data, as Michael Veale (see deliverable 1, Netflix case-study p.6), have warned that Netflix did not ask for permission to store the data with the movie ‘Bandersnatch’.

In this line, it is important to highlight that the company does not merely gather viewing data to see what the audience likes or dislikes  but it helps Netflix to create psychological profiles of the users to market content more efficiently, for example if the user chose to cut up Stefan's dad's body, then maybe the same person would also like to watch a gory horror movie (idem).

Questions about privacy have been linked to the relationship between data and identity in that “what happens to personal data is a deeply serious question if that data in part constitutes who the person is” (Lyon 2003), while Lyon also affirms that the results of classifications influence not only individuals but also entire populations, affecting the choices as well as the chances of those individuals.

Similarly, Bellanova & González Fuster (2018) argue that Netflix not only gathers data from users’ behaviour but have also tried to predict their interests and produce more profitable creations “Netflix has over time acquired the means and the tools to infer its users’ preferences, and to design cultural products tailored to an identified market” (Bellanova & Gonzalez Fuster 2018, p. 3).

“The company processes the data collected (about the movies and about the users) so as to produce and suggest cultural artefacts that may please manifold diverse users’ profiles rather than address a one-fits-all wide audience.

These practices are presented in terms of ‘personalisation’ of a service and a product rather than in terms of users’ surveillance […] But when we realise how Netflix actually works, we may come to finally visualise algorithmic surveillance as an ‘embodied’ practice, a perception overall too rare in many other social settings.

Every move our fingers make on the platform is a trace for an archive about users’ behaviours, and these data, once properly mined, will ‘feed back’ into what we (and others) will be suggested to watch” (Idem p.4-5)

It becomes clear that Netflix has a data-driven business model, which was publicly shown when Netflix announced a 1-million price to improve its recommendation algorithms to interpret user’s behaviors by making available more than a hundred thousand movie ratings from Netflix subscribers from 1999 to 2005 (Idem p.15), and this was possible by removing all personal information.
The authors clearly argue how surveillance is now less about surveilling individuals but the aggregated data and profile identification that helps to produce an audience.

The importance of shows like this one is that “it attempts to visualize both the shift towards a new form of knowledge generation and to question its limits and its everyday integration into current political practices, and does so while being itself a data-driven product supported and distributed by a company grounded on pervasive data collection” (Idem p.14).

This year, Netflix Spain has advertised its first interactive reality show with users , although there is secrecy in what this show will be about, it represents the knowledge-generation based on data, where it was suggested that people pay more attention to reality shows, which keeps them more engaged.
Furthermore, Netflix is producing more interactive shows  following the success of Bandersnatch, which obviously will develop into a more data-generated outputs from users .

This brief analysis is an indicative of how Netflix will produce shows based on data-generation patterns, and users will receive more personalized recommendations based on the decisions of increasingly complex algorithms.
Netflix will also pursue more interactive shows in the future, that will offer more data-generated patterns.

The algorithms at play and recommendations are useful for the company and their business, but they need to be fully accountable for their impact.

Those are considered ‘greedy algorithms’ (Annex 2-1) because they try to maximize the time a user spends on the website, for example the content that are more attracted to you (such as the viral content), and this is particularly important because the platforms need to keep users engaged to, for example, send advertisements or to keep users paying the subscription like Netflix.

However, there is another side of this argument of algorithmic use, as Interviewee 2 argues (Annex 2-2) Netflix recommendation system might not be that important for their business; it even stopped the famous prize to enhance their recommendation system because the advancement in the algorithm was very small.

Content production, rather than individualized content, is one of the most prominent uses of Netflix to know in what shows to invest, and to generate new content, and this use is the one of the most important for Netflix that will continue to develop in the future.

Content production, rather than individualized content, is one of the most prominent uses of Netflix to know in what shows to invest, and to generate new content, and this use is the one of the most important for Netflix that will continue to develop in the future.

Moreover, Netflix website not only deals with personalization, but also the way it is being implemented as a normative way of keeping users engaged, such as with the auto-play in which the TV shows play the next episode automatically (Annex 1-4).

Moreover, Netflix website not only deals with personalization, but also the way it is being implemented as a normative way of keeping users engaged, such as with the auto-play in which the TV shows play the next episode automatically (Annex 1-4).
This greediness and addictiveness, according to interviewee 3 needs to be studied to identify is these platforms are in fact making us more addictive to the screen in the future:

Nevertheless, Netflix still needs to produce good content to keep us engaged because the time we spent is higher than other social networks, but ultimately these platforms want to make sure we stay on these platforms.

It can be derived a negative future in which, on the one hand Netflix will keep developing algorithms that are trying to make us more addictive and which find which shows can keep users more engaged, and on the other hand they need to produce content that make us interested and use the data retrieved to invest in new shows, which it is leading to lower the quality of the series.

It is even showed that the only available resource to understand these algorithms is the ‘Netflix Media Center’ that is useful but also very technical, used for computer scientists or engineers and does not help users to understand their recommendations (Annex 1-4).

Furthermore, it is difficult to have a clear picture of what is really happening at the home screen, Interviewee 1 argues that it is also a series of advertisements in Netflix, not like other advertisements such as with Facebook, Netflix promotes their own shows and movies.

“we're just doing it to bring you a better service, and you know you'll have more content you like and you'll be able to access it more easily […] but then they don't really show […] my homepage is also a series of advertisements” (Annex1-5).

On the contrary, interviewee 3 has argued that there is a counter argument for this bubble, in which there are bubbles everywhere, that we live in the bubble depending on the country that we are immerse in, the friends we have etc.

Recommendation systems are leading into a ‘real-time’ (idem-4), where AI will become more advanced in understanding what users are interested in and will produced TV shows according to these recommendations, and to reduce risk of investment as much as possible for the company.

“where AI can help us create programs, basically when AI creates demand where we become influenced, so basically the algorithm creates some kind of influence, and then influences what we need, so for instance before Facebook was there I didn't think I needed Facebook, but now suddenly I use it every 5 minutes, so there's kind of a shift there, so about the future Netflix, two things, one is that is becoming much better in understanding the needs of the users, and then creating TV programs based on that, and the second one is to use AI to actually create the demand” (idem-4)

“where AI can help us create programs, basically when AI creates demand where we become influenced, so basically the algorithm creates some kind of influence, and then influences what we need, so for instance before Facebook was there I didn't think I needed Facebook, but now suddenly I use it every 5 minutes, so there's kind of a shift there, so about the future Netflix, two things, one is that is becoming much better in understanding the needs of the users, and then creating TV programs based on that, and the second one is to use AI to actually create the demand” (idem-4)
Privacy is definitely an important issue, although Netflix follows the law and regulations of data protection like GDPR, there is still much to consider.
There is a negative view about privacy, in which it is considered that individuals do not care about privacy and how it will not be productive to explain to users their recommendations:
There is a negative view about privacy, in which it is considered that individuals do not care about privacy and how it will not be productive to explain to users their recommendations:
There are discrepancies about what type of data is important for Netflix.
It is necessary to compare the cost of the data (processing power) and the benefit, and it is not relevant to record everything.
It is necessary to compare the cost of the data (processing power) and the benefit, and it is not relevant to record everything.

On the other hand, all the interviewees have agreed that the ‘privacy policies’ or ‘service agreements’ proposed by the law are not useful, in fact, they clearly exposed that nobody reads them (not even interviewee 3 who is a legal scholar and a Netflix subscriber).

On the other hand, all the interviewees have agreed that the ‘privacy policies’ or ‘service agreements’ proposed by the law are not useful, in fact, they clearly exposed that nobody reads them (not even interviewee 3 who is a legal scholar and a Netflix subscriber).
It is also important to question how the data is being used after a user leave the platform.

Moreover, it was also pointed out by the legal scholar how there was up until the moment no data breach in this company (annex 3-1), however, if this would be the case, a lot of sensitive information will be revealed.
It is also important to question how the data is being used after a user leave the platform.
It is also important to question how the data is being used after a user leave the platform.
Still, the legal scholar trusts the way Netflix handles the data.
In addition, it still exists the risk in the future to access the data from third-party sectors like the police, such as “predictive policing”:

“You should see a movie that they got the killer through access to a library catalog,  because of the reading habits, this is sensitive data, I told you before, I would not be happy that I was sold, and it is sensitive and it says a lot about an individual, therefore, yes it could happen” (annex 3-4)

“You should see a movie that they got the killer through access to a library catalog,  because of the reading habits, this is sensitive data, I told you before, I would not be happy that I was sold, and it is sensitive and it says a lot about an individual, therefore, yes it could happen” (annex 3-4)
Finally, interactivity such as with Bandersnatch (section 2.2) is argued as a more data-generated pattern and this will continue in the future with more movies like the one mentioned.

However, as the legal scholar points out, this is not new and the technology already exists (annex 3-2) and this will not be the dominant position, because people still want to see the content that a director or novelist thought of.

Current business models deal with finding patterns in the data to know what users want, but they do not engage with the audience, as their algorithms are hidden, and there is a lack of explainability and autonomy.

Thus, more efforts should be made in this platform on the values of autonomy and explainability in the future, and it is argued that mor efforts, derived from regulatory practices and chilling effects, could lead to make Netflix more accountable and offer more control over people’s preferences.

Although it seems easy to understand how these recommendation systems work as exposed by the experts, such as if a user like drama, more dramas will be recommended, the previous deliverable of this project did not show this.

Although it seems easy to understand how these recommendation systems work as exposed by the experts, such as if a user like drama, more dramas will be recommended, the previous deliverable of this project did not show this.

The value of data cannot be taken for granted, as it reveals a lot of psychological information about yourself, and these algorithms are creating a profile based on this, which relates to the already exposed filter bubble.

The value of data cannot be taken for granted, as it reveals a lot of psychological information about yourself, and these algorithms are creating a profile based on this, which relates to the already exposed filter bubble.
Thus, quality is an important value, that it can be misleading by data-generated patterns in which algorithms ‘show’ that people are more interested in less-quality content.
Datafication of Netflix has been proven as a method that cannot be stopped due to the importance of data-generation, but privacy is an important value that one must remember:

In addition, it has been argued that Netflix is part of Amazon , and the worries about a future in which Amazon’s products and data will be integrated into Netflix’s recommendations (such as if you buy a book, and there is a movie about it, it will be recommended to you).
Datafication of Netflix has been proven as a method that cannot be stopped due to the importance of data-generation, but privacy is an important value that one must remember:

“Now with Amazon Alexa with apple Siri, and apple has a TV channel […] it becomes a lot more integrated in the experience of a family, of a person, of their house, how they experience content, that I would say is a much stronger future, so in terms of not saying the future within Netflix it's more what's going to happen with Netflix within the broader ecosystem of Amazon and all the data that is involved with that – so Does the Amazon recommendation system for the movies cannot use my shopping history?

cannot use my Alexa conversations?
Thus, data and algorithms have been shown relevant to produce recommendations, but there is a lack of privacy that needs to be considered.

This data can continue to be developed in the future with data-generated movies like interactive movies, where even kids are profiled and that makes them more addictive.

Companies like this could be more ethically oriented and study other forms of existing without surveilling their users and generate content with less quality, but it seems that this is not the paths that are taken in the near future:

“I think could be really liberating I think for other organizations of technology and other more ethical oriented and socially useful ways that these platform technologies could exist outside an advertising domination model” (annex 1-1).

“I think could be really liberating I think for other organizations of technology and other more ethical oriented and socially useful ways that these platform technologies could exist outside an advertising domination model” (annex 1-1).
Moreover, the power dynamics that are at stake within this company also supports the need to give more autonomy and explanation to the use of their recommendation systems.

“their power isn't communicated, it's like you technically consent to these things but never actually reads them so there is an interesting dynamic but I think it is a part of the game of the Internet or it's designed for convenience and for like pleasurable user experiences and reading long legal documents is definitely not part of that so it's designed in such a way that you're going to just click yes and then move on to whatever you want to do” (annex 1-3)
